Description: Left fist, grasping a roll, from a colossal red granite statue of Ramses II.
Curator's comments: In addition to the representation of the fist as found by the Napoleonic expedition (Description V, pl. 3-4), it is described as having been found at the South-East angle of the ruins and was discovered with other fragments in pink granite, including the shoulder, the forearm, fragments of the torso and limbs. The left fist was the best preserved fragment. See Description de l'Egypte, vol. 5. Antiquités, descriptions, p. 540-1 H. Sourouzian (Catalogue de la statuaire royale de la XIXe dynastie, BdE 177, 2019, p. 666) suggests that the statue was originally carved for Sesostris I, and reused by Ramses II.
Bibliography: Bonparte et l’Égypte, Paris 2008, no. 223.
